name: SST
headline: Build modern full-stack applications on your own infrastructure
description: SST is an open-source framework that makes it easy to build modern full-stack applications on your own infrastructure.

sst.config.ts```

const db = newplanetscale.Database("Db")
const email = newsst.aws.Email("Email", {
sender: "mail@example.com"
})
const api = newsst.aws.Service("Api", {
memory: "4 GB",
image: "./rails",
link: [db, email]
})
const web = newsst.aws.Nextjs("Web", {
link: [api],
path: "./nextjs",
domain: "example.com",
dns: sst.cloudflare.dns()
})

```

# For whatever you build.
Deploy everything your app needs with a single config.
`npm i\xa0sst`

generated_description:
SST is a company that's making waves in the developer tools space, especially within the realm of open-source frameworks. Founded in 2010 and part of the Y Combinator Batch W21, SST calls Toronto, Canada home, and operates with a lean team of just three people. The mission is straightforward: to help developers build modern full-stack applications using their own infrastructure, simplifying the complex web development landscape.

Initially launched as an open-source framework, SST empowers developers by providing a cohesive way to manage their applications with a single configuration. This approach targets those who want complete control over their deployment environments—whether it’s on the cloud or on-premises. We'll get into the benefits, but first, let’s touch on what they’re doing.

SST enables you to deploy all components of your application—databases, APIs, and front-end—all with just a few lines of code. For instance, developers can set up a database connection with PlanetScale, configure an email service using AWS, and deploy a Next.js application—all in one go. It’s this level of simplicity and integration that has attracted a following among development teams, evidenced by their growing GitHub community.

With its clear focus on being a developer-first tool, SST thrives in a niche marked by rapid innovation and constant learning. Engaging with their resources, like their [blog](https://sst.dev/blog) and [documentation](https://sst.dev/docs), showcases their commitment to an open-source ethos, allowing developers to not only use but also contribute back to the framework. 

So if you’re a developer looking to streamline your workflow while keeping control of your infrastructure, SST could be your new best friend. It's a great example of how targeted tools can enable creators to focus on building rather than managing—and in the fast-paced world of tech, that’s a significant advantage. You can explore more about what they offer on their website: [sst.dev](https://sst.dev).
